title: 112_s3532
content: The "Church Plan Clarification Act of 2012" may be cited as the Act. It clarifies church plans. The "Church Plan Clarification Act of 2012" clarifies the application of Controlled Group Rules to Church Plans under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. It specifies that organizations eligible for church plans are not aggregated unless certain conditions are met. The Church Plan Clarification Act of 2012 clarifies that organizations providing at least 80% of operating funds to another organization, with common management or supervision, are subject to specific rules under the Internal Revenue Code. The Church Plan Clarification Act of 2012 states that nonqualified church-controlled organizations can be treated as a single employer if at least 80% of their directors or trustees are affiliated with the first organization. The Church Plan Clarification Act of 2012 allows nonqualified church-controlled organizations to elect to be treated as under common control for tax purposes. This election can be made by the church or association of churches they are associated with. The Church Plan Clarification Act of 2012 allows organizations to disaggregate entities in church plans. An anti-abuse rule applies, and the amendments are effective for taxable years. Contribution and funding limitations apply to 403(b) grandfathered defined benefit plans. Grandfathered Defined Benefit Plans under the Tax Equity and Fiscal Responsibility Act of 1982 are amended to be subject to the limitations of section 415(b) as if it were a defined benefit plan under section 401(a) and not the limitations of section 415(c) for defined contribution plans. The amendments apply retroactively to the enactment of the Act. Additionally, Church Plans are now allowed automatic enrollment. Church Plans are now allowed automatic enrollment, superseding any state laws that would restrict this inclusion. An automatic contribution arrangement allows participants to elect for the plan sponsor to make contributions on their behalf. An automatic contribution arrangement allows the plan sponsor to make contributions on behalf of participants until they opt out or choose a different percentage. Plan administrators must provide participants with notice of their rights and obligations under the arrangement before each plan year. The notice for an automatic contribution arrangement must be comprehensive, written in a way understandable to participants, and include election requirements such as the right to opt out or choose a different contribution percentage. The participant must be given a reasonable period to make an election after receiving a notice about contributions and their investment. This subsection will be effective upon the enactment of the Act. Additionally, certain plan transfers and mergers are allowed under Section 414 of the Internal Revenue Code. Certain plan transfers and mergers are allowed under Section 414 of the Internal Revenue Code, where no amount is includible in gross income by reason of transferring account balances between certain church plans and annuity contracts maintained by the same church or association of churches. Transfers and mergers of account balances between church plans and annuity contracts maintained by the same church or association of churches are allowed under Section 414 of the Internal Revenue Code. Transfers and mergers of account balances between church plans and annuity contracts maintained by the same church or association of churches are allowed under Section 414 of the Internal Revenue Code. The limitations and qualifications for such transfers or mergers are outlined in the subsection, including ensuring that the participant's or beneficiary's benefits are not reduced as a result. The definitions of "church" and "annuity contract" are also provided for clarity. The amendment allows transfers or mergers of account balances between church plans and annuity contracts, including custodial accounts and retirement income accounts. The effective date for this amendment is after the enactment of the Act. Additionally, church plans can invest in collective trusts under certain conditions outlined in the Internal Revenue Code. The amendment allows church plans to invest in group trusts described in IRS Revenue Ruling 81-100 without affecting their tax status. This applies after the enactment of the Act. The subsection on group trust investments applies to investments made after the enactment of the Act.
